q: How can you ease headaches yourself?
a: You can drink plenty of water, get plenty of rest, try to relax, take paracetamol or ibuprofen, and avoid alcohol, skipping meals, and straining your eyes for a long time.

q: When should you see a GP for your headaches?
a: You should see a GP if your headache keeps coming back, painkillers do not help and your headache gets worse, or if you have a severe throbbing pain, feel sick, vomit, and find light or noise painful.

q: What is the urgent advice for severe headaches?
a: If you or your child has a severe headache along with jaw pain when eating, blurred or double vision, sore scalp, numbness or weakness in the arms or legs, or other concerning symptoms, you should get an urgent GP appointment or call 111.

q: When should you call 999 or go to A&E for headaches?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you or your child has a head injury, a suddenly extremely painful headache, sudden problems speaking or remembering things, loss of vision, drowsiness or confusion, very high temperature and symptoms of meningitis, or if your child has specific symptoms along with a headache.

q: What are some common causes of headaches?
a: Common causes of headaches include having a cold or flu, stress, drinking too much alcohol, bad posture, eyesight problems, not eating regular meals, dehydration, taking too many painkillers, and hormonal changes during menstruation or menopause.

q: Can stress cause headaches?
i: Stress is a known cause of headaches.
a: Yes, stress can cause headaches.

q: Can dehydration lead to headaches?
i: Not drinking enough fluids can cause dehydration.
a: Yes, dehydration can lead to headaches.

q: How can bad posture contribute to headaches?
i: Sitting or standing with incorrect posture can strain the muscles in the neck and head.
a: Bad posture can strain the muscles in the neck and head, leading to headaches.

q: Are eyesight problems a common cause of headaches?
i: Having uncorrected vision problems may contribute to headaches.
a: Yes, eyesight problems can be a common cause of headaches, especially if the vision is uncorrected.

q: Can taking too many painkillers cause headaches?
i: Taking excessive amounts of painkillers can have side effects.
a: Yes, taking too many painkillers can lead to headaches as a side effect.

q: How can you ease headaches yourself?
a: To ease headaches yourself, you can try drinking plenty of water, getting plenty of rest, relaxing to reduce stress, taking paracetamol or ibuprofen, and avoiding alcohol and skipping meals.

q: When should you see a GP for your headache?
i: Your headache keeps coming back and painkillers do not help, or you have a bad throbbing pain at the front or side of your head and feel sick, vomit, or find light/noise painful.
a: You should see a GP if your headache is recurring, painkillers don't work, or you have severe symptoms like throbbing pain, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light/noise.

q: When should you seek urgent advice for your headache?
i: Your headache is severe with jaw pain when eating, blurred or double vision, sore scalp, or other symptoms like numbness/weakness in arms or legs.
a: You should seek urgent advice if your headache is severe with additional symptoms like jaw pain, vision issues, sore scalp, or numbness/weakness in limbs.

q: What immediate action should you take for an extremely painful headache?
i: Your headache came on suddenly and is extremely painful, or you have an extremely painful headache with sudden problems speaking, remembering, loss of vision, or drowsiness/confusion.
a: For an extremely painful headache, you should call emergency services or go to A&E if you experience sudden onset, extreme pain, or additional symptoms like speech problems, vision loss, or confusion.

q: When should you immediately call 999 or go to A&E for a headache?
i: You have a head injury, an extremely painful headache, or a very high temperature with symptoms of meningitis.
a: You should immediately call 999 or go to A&E if you have a head injury, an extremely painful headache, high fever with meningitis symptoms, or severe symptoms in the case of a child.

q: What are some common reasons that can cause headaches?
a: Some common reasons that can cause headaches include having a cold or flu, stress, drinking too much alcohol, bad posture, eyesight problems, irregular meals, dehydration, excessive painkiller use, and hormonal factors during periods or menopause.

q: What are some ways to ease headaches yourself?
i: Most headaches go away on their own and are not a sign of something more serious.
a: You can ease headaches by drinking plenty of water, getting plenty of rest, trying to relax, taking painkillers like paracetamol or ibuprofen, and avoiding alcohol and skipping meals.

q: When should you see a GP for a headache?
a: You should see a GP if your headache keeps coming back, painkillers do not help and your headache gets worse, or if you have a severe throbbing pain, feel nauseous, vomit, or have sensitivity to light or noise.

q: What are some urgent signs requiring immediate medical attention for a headache?
a: You should seek urgent medical attention or call 111 if you or your child have a severe headache with jaw pain when eating, blurred or double vision, sore scalp, numbness or weakness in the arms or legs. If your child is under 12 and has specific symptoms, such as waking up with a headache, progressively worsening headache, or headache with vomiting.

q: When should you call 999 or go to A&E for a headache?
a: You should call 999 or go to A&E if you or your child have a head injury, a sudden and extremely painful headache, sudden problems speaking or remembering things, loss of vision, or a very high temperature and symptoms of meningitis. If your child is under 12 and has specific symptoms, such as vision problems, difficulty speaking or walking, persistent lack of energy, or a headache starting within 5 days of a head injury.

q: What are some common causes of headaches?
a: Some common causes of headaches are having a cold or flu, stress, drinking too much alcohol, bad posture, eyesight problems, irregular eating habits, dehydration, excessive painkiller use, and hormonal changes during menstruation or menopause.
